descriptionSet.description: In this calender from 1950 an advertisement for Asli Sher Chhap Bidis (Authentic Tiger Brand Bidis) can be seen. A packet of bidis with a lion printed on it can be seen in the centre. In the background we see a map of South Asia as well as various types of men smoking bidis - a bearded man with a turban, a priest wearing a sacred thread, a merchant with a turban, a young man and a couple of other men.

inscription.text: रजिस्टर न. ५०४ असली तमाखूकी शेर- छाप- बिडी. एक वक़्त पीकर खात्री करो
बिडी [on the packet] जबलपूर मोहनलाल हरगोविंद
हिंदुस्थानमें मशहूर बीडीयोंका कारखाना मोहनलाल हरगोविंददास, जबलपूर
Asli Sher Chhap Bidi. Register n. 504. Sher-Chhap Bidi. Ek vakt pikar khatri karo.
Nakli malse saavdhaan raho. Nakli mal bananewalopar kaarvai hogi.
Hindustan mein mashhoor bidiyon ka karkhaana Mohanlal Hargovinddas, Jabalpur

hra:item.hra:value: text-hi: असली शेर छाप बिडी
text-hi: रजिस्टर न. ५०४ असली तमाखूकी शेर- छाप- बिडी. एक वक़्त पीकर खात्री करो
text-hi: नकली मालसे सावधान रहो
text-hi: नकली माल बनानेवालॊंपर कारवाई होगी
text-hi: बिडी [on the packet] जबलपूर मोहनलाल हरगोविंद
text-hi: हिंदुस्थानमें मशहूर बीडीयोंका कारखाना मोहनलाल हरगोविंददास, जबलपूर
text-transcription-hi: Asli Sher Chhap Bidi. Register n. 504. Sher-Chhap Bidi. Ek vakt pikar khatri karo.
text-transcription-hi: Nakli malse saavdhaan raho. Nakli mal bananewalopar kaarvai hogi.
text-transcription-hi: Hindustan mein mashhoor bidiyon ka karkhaana Mohanlal Hargovinddas, Jabalpur
text-en: Mohanlal Hargovind Jubbulpore BIDI No. 7
text-en: REGD. No: 504
text-en: 1950

description-en: In this calender from 1950 an advertisement for Asli Sher Chhap Bidis (Authentic Tiger Brand Bidis) can be seen. A packet of bidis with a lion printed on it can be seen in the centre. In the background we see a map of South Asia as well as various types of men smoking bidis - a bearded man with a turban, a priest wearing a sacred thread, a merchant with a turban, a young man and a couple of other men. (sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The advertisement declares Mohanlal Hargovind Das of Jabalpur as makers of beedi [country cigarettes] with authentic tobacco that bring satisfaction with one puff. It also warns customers to beware of fake beedis as well as threatens legal action against those who would produce such fakes. Note that the calendar is in English while much of the rest of the ad is in Hindi. (Sumathi Ramaswamy) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: A partly visible map of India—all its new borders and frontiers erased—is shown occupied by a beedi packet, and male bodies variously attired to signify different regional, sectarian and caste communities. On the one hand, the use of the map form allows the makers of Sher Chhaap bidi to announce the all-India popularity of their product. To be Indian, the ad seems to implicitly suggest by drawing upon and deploying the map of India, is to also smoke Indian. (Sumathi Ramaswamy) (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: Even a pandit is depicted smoking on this object. Pandits usually are not allowed to indulge in smoking. (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: A bidi is a type of cigarette common in south Asia in which a tendu leaf is filled with tobacco, rolled and tied with string. (sp)
related literature: Menon, V.P. 1956. The Story of the Integration of the Indian States. New York: Macmillan. (gs)
related literature: Nair, P. Thankappan. 1987. Indian National Songs and Symbols. Calcutta: Firma KLM Pvt. Ltd, pp. 74-97. (gs)
related literature: Neumayer, Erwin, and Christine Schelberger. 2008. "Bharat mata: India's freedom movement in popular art". Delhi: Oxford University Press. (gs)
related literature: Ramaswamy, Sumathi 2010. The Goddess and the Nation. Mapping Mother India. London: Duke University Press. (gs)

related literature: Ramaswamy, Sumathi 2011. "Artful Mapping in Bazaar India. Cartographic Reflections on the Priya Paul Collection". http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/116/index_1.html, last accessed 2011-03-30 (gs)

Ramaswamy, Sumathi 2011. "Artful Mapping in Bazaar India. Cartographic Reflections on the Priya Paul Collection". http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/116/index_1.html, last accessed 2011-03-30
Neumayer, Erwin, and Christine Schelberger. 2008. "Bharat mata: India's freedom movement in popular art". Delhi: Oxford University Press.
